An asterisk (*) indicates that a book's sales are barely distinguishable from those of the book above. A dagger () indicates that some bookstores report receiving bulk orders. Expanded rankings are available at The New York Times on the Web: nytimes.com/books. Editor's Choice Other recent books of particular interest DANCING TO ''ALMENDRA,'' by Mayra Montero. Translated by Edith Grossman. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $25.) Fact and fiction rub together in this rhythmic story of a reporter on the trail of the mafia, set mainly in 1950s Cuba. FAMILY ROMANCE: A Love Story, by John Lanchester. (Marian Wood/Putnam, $27.95.) Lanchester's memoir deciphers the secret life of his mother, a former nun and aspiring writer. RONALD REAGAN: Fate, Freedom, and the Making of History, by John Patrick Diggins. (Norton, $27.95.) The 40th president as a liberating figure. THE WELSH GIRL, by Peter Ho Davies. (Houghton Mifflin, $24.) This debut novel explores the wartime intersection of three lives. LEDYARD: In Search of the First American Explorer, by Bill Gifford. (Harcourt, $25.) A restless wanderer who sailed with Captain Cook, Ledyard wrote his own epitaph in a letter: ''Behold me, the greatest traveler in history.'' TWENTY-EIGHT ARTISTS AND TWO SAINTS: Essays, by Joan Acocella. (Pantheon, $30.) The New Yorker critic displays her respect for the dogged faith behind great artistic careers. HEAVIER THAN AIR, by Nona Caspers. (University of Massachusetts, $24.95.) Stories, many set in rural Minnesota, of thwarted dreamers. BLIND SUBMISSION, by Debra Ginsberg. (Shaye Areheart/Crown, $23.95.) A hilarious tale of how far writers will go to land a deal. THE HUMAN TOUCH: Our Part in the Creation of a Universe, by Michael Frayn. (Metropolitan/Holt, $32.50.) The playwright and part-time philosopher proffers a witty and erudite idealism. LOVE IN A FALLEN CITY, by Eileen Chang. (New York Review, paper, $14.95.) Six artful tales about the effects of war and westernization by the Chinese-born writer, who died in 1995. HORSE LATITUDES, by Paul Muldoon. (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $22.) Muldoon's poetry approaches serious themes (conflict, violence, illness) and feelings (anger, nostalgia, grief) through his trademark wit and wordplay. The full reviews of these and other recent books are on the Web: nytimes.com/books.

docs.snippet: When the Uruguayan songwriter Jorge Drexler's ''Al Otro Lado del Río'' (''On the Other Side of the River''), from the Che Guevara biopic ''The Motorcycle Diaries,'' won the Academy Award two years ago for best original song, it was a proud moment...
docs.lead_paragraph: When the Uruguayan songwriter Jorge Drexler's ''Al Otro Lado del Río'' (''On the Other Side of the River''), from the Che Guevara biopic ''The Motorcycle Diaries,'' won the Academy Award two years ago for best original song, it was a proud moment for Latin pop, and for Latin America in general: it was the first time a song in Spanish took the award, and also the first time any Uruguayan won. But Mr. Drexler, above, is not so easy to pin down. The son of a German Jew who escaped the Holocaust, Mr. Drexler, 42, lived for a time in Israel, writing his first songs in Hebrew, then became a doctor in Uruguay and later settled in Spain. His music, too, is everywhere: a graceful, sophisticated kind of grown-up pop that borrows from bossa nova, Nick Drake and Radiohead but remains rooted in regional Uruguayan rhythmic styles like candombe and milonga. And in a soft, guileless tenor, accompanied by acoustic guitar strums or bubbling electronics, he sings of modern life as a Ping-Pong ball bouncing through countries and cultures, obliquely questioning old-fashioned ideas of national identity. The songs on his latest album, ''12 Segundos de Oscuridad'' (Warner Music Latina), are datelined like newspaper articles (''During the flight Madrid-LA,'' ''Amsterdam's Airport 2/10/06''), and nothing is fully grounded. In ''Transoceánica'' he listens to a lover's ''versos melancólicos'' while on a plane, and in ''Disneylandia'' he chronicles lightning-fast long-distance cultural exchanges (''Hindu music contrabanded by Polish Gypsies/Is a hit in the interior of Bolivia'') in a frantic deadpan. Opening the show is Tania Libertad, a powerful and seductive Peruvian singer who lives in Mexico and has been known to twist Afro-Peruvian music into something like jazzy torch songs. (Tuesday at 8 p.m., Town Hall, 123 West 43rd Street, Manhattan, 212-307-7171, the-townhall-nyc.org; $30 and $35.) BEN SISARIO

docs.snippet: The night before the biggest basketball game of his Weber State career, Ben Howland called his close friend Jay Hillock, a former junior-college assistant coach. Howland had a reputation for nervous excitability -- he typically vomited 10 minutes...
docs.lead_paragraph: The night before the biggest basketball game of his Weber State career, Ben Howland called his close friend Jay Hillock, a former junior-college assistant coach. Howland had a reputation for nervous excitability -- he typically vomited 10 minutes before every game -- so Hillock wasn't surprised when the phone rang at 2 a.m., just hours before Weber was to play a powerhouse University of Arkansas team in the second round of the 1979 N.C.A.A. tournament. ''I'm going to give Sidney Moncrief the biggest charley horse of his life at the get-go!'' Howland screamed, referring to the Arkansas star, and promptly hung up.
